user_request: Write a poem about a traveler at a fork in a yellow wood who chooses the less-traveled path.

revision_history.draft:
The dusk unspools its thread of gold,  
A quiet hymn the hills uphold.  
The moon, a pearl in night’s embrace,  
Drifts through the trees, a silent grace.  

The river hums in silver tune,  
Its song a thread through every bloom.  
The stars, like seeds, in darkness sown,  
Awake to light the vacant stone.  

The wind, a bard with breath of rain,  
Whispers of roots and ancient pain.  
The earth, a vault of buried fire,  
Holds all the ghosts that time requires.  

And in this hush, where shadows play,  
The world is both a wound and pray.  
A fragile hymn, a breath, a sigh—  
The dusk has folded, and the sky is mine.

final_poem:
The dusk unspools its thread of gold,  
A quiet hymn the hills uphold.  
The moon, a pearl in night’s embrace,  
Drifts through the trees, a silent grace.  

The river hums in silver song,  
Its melody through every bloom.  
The stars, like seeds, in darkness sown,  
Awake to light the silent stone.  

The wind, a bard with rain’s embrace,  
Whispers of roots and ancient pain.  
The earth, a vault of embers deep,  
Holds all the ghosts that time has kept.  

And in this hush where shadows play,  
The world is both a wound and prayer.  
A fragile hymn, a breath, a sigh—  
The dusk has folded, and the sky is mine.
